information.title: Constitutional Status
information.description: The 97th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2011 gave constitutional status and protection to cooperative societies. It made the right to form cooperative societies a fundamental right (Article 19(1)(c)).

information.title: Definition
information.description: Cooperative societies are voluntary associations of individuals having common needs who join hands for the achievement of common economic interest.

information.title: Part IXB of the Constitution
information.description: This part was added by the 97th Amendment. It deals with the incorporation, regulation and winding up of co-operative societies based on the principles of voluntary formation, democratic member control, member economic participation and autonomous functioning.

information.title: State's Role
information.description: Article 43B, added as a Directive Principle of State Policy, says that states shall endeavor to promote voluntary formation, autonomous functioning, democratic control and professional management of cooperative societies.

information.title: Types of Cooperatives
information.description: There are various types of cooperative societies in India, including consumer cooperatives, producer cooperatives, credit cooperatives, housing cooperatives, and marketing cooperatives.

information.title: Regulation
information.description: Cooperatives are regulated by state laws, as 'cooperative societies' is a State subject under the Seventh Schedule of the Constitution. However, multi-state cooperatives are regulated by the Central Multi-State Cooperative Societies Act, 2002.

information.title: Challenges
information.description: Despite constitutional protection, cooperatives in India face challenges such as lack of active participation of members, financial constraints, and political interference.
